channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Chiomonte Journal: Italy Divided Over Rail Line Meant to Unite
item.description: A two-decade debate over a high-speed rail line between Italy and France reveals broad cultural and political differences within Italy.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.media:credit: Fabio Bucciarelli for The New York Times
item.media:description: Opponents of the Treno Alta Velocita rail project met this month in the Susa Valley. After 20 years of controversy, construction began in 2011.

item.title: Deterioration in U.S.-Russian Relations May Disrupt Iran Nuclear Talks
item.description: The second round of negotiations on a nuclear agreement with Iran is set to begin Tuesday and success hinges on solidarity among the members of the United Nations Security Council.
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: Jewish State Declaration an Unyielding Block to Deal
item.description: As a peace agreement deadline loomed, President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority refused to utter the language Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has insisted be applied in recognition of Israel.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: Palestinians in Ramallah held a rally in support of Mr. Abbas.

item.title: In Eastern Ukraine, the Curtain Goes Up, and the Clash Begins
item.description: Set against a backdrop of revolution, secession and the possibility of war, this was a sort of street theater that has been used by both sides in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: By C. J. CHIVERS and ANDREW ROTH
item.media:description: Pro-Russia protesters in Kharkiv, Ukraine, tried briefly on Sunday to push their way into the regional administration building.

item.title: The Lede: Murdoch Urges Irish to Boycott Guinness Over Its Embrace of Gay Rights
item.description: Rupert Murdoch’s call for the people of Ireland and their cousins in the diaspora to defend the honor of the St. Patrick’s Day Parade in Manhattan by boycotting Guinness appeared to generate little support.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Matter: A Growth Spurt at 1,500 Years Old
item.description: Researchers at the British Antarctic Survey have revived moss that had been lying dormant in permafrost for a millennium and a half.
item.dc:creator: By CARL ZIMMER
item.media:description: Drilling on a moss bank on Signy Island off Antarctica. In the cores drawn from ground, researchers saw moss shoots. One core was sent to a lab in Britain, and was put under a lamp and misted from time to time. After being frozen for more than 1,500 years, the moss was growing again.

item.title: Questions Over Absence of Cellphone Calls From Missing Flight’s Passengers
item.description: Some theorize that the missing Malaysia Airlines jet flight was flying too high for the use of personal electronic devices after it was diverted.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER
item.media:description: Relatives of passengers who were traveling on Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 watched a news conference at a hotel in Beijing on Monday.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Out of Control
item.description: Why can pilots still shut off transponders?
item.dc:creator: By GREGG EASTERBROOK

item.title: China Releases Plan to Incorporate Farmers Into Cities
item.description: An ambitious government blueprint is the country’s first attempt to broadly coordinate the introduction of hundreds of millions of rural residents into cities.
item.dc:creator: By IAN JOHNSON
item.media:description: New apartment buildings for former miners and farmers in a suburb of Beijing.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese News Agency Slams Delays in Search for Jet
item.description: China’s state-run news agency, Xinhua, criticized the Malaysian authorities, saying that the search for the missing aircraft, with mostly Chinese passengers aboard, has wasted time and resources.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Defying Sanctions, Putin Declares Crimea Independent
item.description: Brushing aside Western condemnation, President Vladimir V. Putin decreed Crimea was independent from Ukraine, a possible precursor to annexation.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN LEE MYERS, PETER BAKER and ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:description: Cossacks installed a Russian flag and a Crimean flag on the roof of the City Hall building on Monday in Bakhchysarai, a city in central Crimea.

item.title: SEAL Team Raids a Tanker and Thwarts a Militia’s Bid to Sell Libyan Oil
item.description: The American operation saved the fragile transitional government in Tripoli from a potentially catastrophic loss of control over its main source of revenue and last source of power: Libya’s vast oil reserves.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: 3 Activists Held In Sri Lanka, Raising Fears Of Crackdown
item.description: The detention of three activists in the last few days sent a ripple of dread through Sri Lanka’s human rights organizations.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS and DHARISHA BASTIANS

item.title: Canada Explores G.M. Link to Accidents
item.description: Canada is looking into whether a fatal crash last June is related to the automaker’s faulty ignition switches.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Malaysia Backtracks on When Airliner’s Communications Were Disabled
item.description: The authorities said Monday that they could not pinpoint precisely when the system was turned off, reversing earlier assertions.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER and CHRISTOPHER BUCKLEY
item.media:description: A Malaysia Airlines Boeing 777-200ER, flight 318 to Beijing, sat on the tarmac Monday at Kuala Lumpur International Airport. Flight 318 replaces 370, retired out of respect to the passengers and crew of the missing plane.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Catholic Bishop Who Spent Decades in Prison Dies in Shanghai
item.description: Bishop Joseph Fan Zhongliang, who was imprisoned for more than two decades in China and spent his final years under house arrest, died on Sunday at age 95, a Roman Catholic organization said.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:credit: The Cardinal Kung Foundation/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: India Ink: On Stage, ‘Nirbhaya’ Gives Delhi Gang Rape Victim a Voice
item.description: An award-winning play that aims to break the silence on violence against women is opening in India after drawing strong reviews in Britain.
item.dc:creator: By SUHASINI RAJ
item.media:description: Priyanka Bose, one of the actors in the play 'Nirbhaya,' which is based on the Delhi gang rape in 2012.

item.title: Ultranationalist-Turned-Liberal Is Expected to Lead Serbia
item.description: Aleksandar Vucic, expected to be Serbia’s next prime minister, recast himself as a pro-Western liberal in a transformation viewed as remarkable.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Text: Obama’s Statement on New Sanctions Against Russia
item.description: Following is a transcript of President Obama’s announcements of new sanctions in response to Russian actions in Ukraine.

item.title: The Lede: Russia Could Still Turn U.S. ‘Into Radioactive Dust,’ News Anchor in Moscow Reminds Viewers
item.description: One of Russia’s most influential television hosts appeared on the evening news Sunday to remind viewers that Russia is still “the only country in the world capable of turning the U.S.A. into radioactive dust.”
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: Russia's ambassador to the United Nations, Vitaly I. Churkin, was confronted by his American counterpart, Samantha Power, on Saturday before a Security Council meeting on the status of Crimea.

item.title: Kerry Announces U.S. Representative to Syrian Opposition
item.description: Daniel Rubinstein, a senior foreign service official fill the position vacated by Robert S. Ford, who retired last month.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: Fighting Pollution, Paris Imposes Partial Driving Ban
item.description: High pollution levels prompted the authorities to order the limits, and public transport in the French capital remained free for a fourth consecutive day.
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT SAYARE
item.media:description: Police officers in Paris were deployed to stop and fine the drivers of vehicles with even-numbered license plates.

item.title: Space Ripples Seen as Big Bang’s Smoking Gun
item.description: Astronomers looking back 13.8 billion years found ripples in the fabric of space-time that support the theory of a universe being wrenched violently apart around its inception.
item.dc:creator: By DENNIS OVERBYE
item.media:credit: Rick Friedman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Alan Guth was one of the first physicists to hypothesize the existence of inflation, which explains how the universe expanded so uniformly and so quickly in the instant after the Big Bang 13.8 billion years ago.

item.title: Markets Worldwide Brush Off Crimea Vote
item.description: The Euro Stoxx 50 index in Europe rose 1.5 percent, while the FTSE 100 index in London gained 0.6 percent, and Russia’s currency backed off record lows and was trading at 36.27 rubles to the dollar.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID JOLLY

item.title: Lawmakers in Crimea Move Swiftly to Split From Ukraine
item.description: The Crimean Parliament declared its independence from Ukraine and formally asked to join Russia, and while Moscow embraced the move, the Kremlin has not declared its intentions.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN and ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: People waved Russian flags at Lenin Square on Monday in Simferopol, the Crimean capital.
